user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of can_compress:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
can_compress (struct MHD_Connection *con)
{
  const char *ae;
  const char *de;

  ae = MHD_lookup_connection_value (con,
                                    MHD_HEADER_KIND,
                                    MHD_HTTP_HEADER_ACCEPT_ENCODING);
  if (NULL == ae)
    return MHD_NO;
  if (0 == strcmp (ae,
                   "*"))
    return MHD_YES;
  de = strstr (ae,
               "deflate");
  if (NULL == de)
    return MHD_NO;
  if (((de == ae) ||
       (de[-1] == ',') ||
       (de[-1] == ' ')) &&
      ((de[strlen ("deflate")] == '\0') ||
       (de[strlen ("deflate")] == ',') ||
       (de[strlen ("deflate")] == ';')))
    return MHD_YES;
  return MHD_NO;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function can_compress:
_MHD_EXTERN const char *
MHD_lookup_connection_value (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                             enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                             const char *key)
{
  const char *value;

  value = NULL;
  (void) MHD_lookup_connection_value_n (connection,
                                        kind,
                                        key,
                                        (NULL == key) ? 0 : strlen (key),
                                        &value,
                                        NULL);
  return value;
}
...
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_lookup_connection_value_n (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                               enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                               const char *key,
                               size_t key_size,
                               const char **value_ptr,
                               size_t *value_size_ptr)
{
  struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header *pos;

  if (NULL == connection)
    return MHD_NO;

  if (NULL == key)
  {
    for (pos = connection->rq.headers_received; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)
    {
      if ( (0 != (kind & pos->kind)) &&
           (NULL == pos->header) )
        break;
    }
  }
  else
  {
    for (pos = connection->rq.headers_received; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)
    {
      if ( (0 != (kind & pos->kind)) &&
           (key_size == pos->header_size) &&
           ( (key == pos->header) ||
             (MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (key,
                                             pos->header,
                                             key_size) ) ) )
        break;
    }
  }

  if (NULL == pos)
    return MHD_NO;

  if (NULL != value_ptr)
    *value_ptr = pos->value;

  if (NULL != value_size_ptr)
    *value_size_ptr = pos->value_size;

  return MHD_YES;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No direct use of memcmp appears in the provided code fragments. The code uses strcmp, strstr and strlen (e.g. if (0 == strcmp(ae, "*")), de = strstr(ae, "deflate"), de[strlen("deflate")] == '\0'), which are appropriate for null-terminated string operations and are not violations of Rule 21.14. The only called helper that might conceivably use memcmp internally is MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_, but it is invoked with an explicit length (key_size) and is intended for binary/length-based comparison rather than comparing null-terminated strings; therefore, based on the shown code there is no evidence of memcmp being used to compare null-terminated strings. If the implementation of MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (not provided) itself used memcmp on null-terminated strings, that implementation should be inspected, but that implementation is not part of the supplied code. Consequently there are no suspicious fragments in the given code that require investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14.
